coredata.dc:title: Numerical Solution for Kawahara Equation by Using Spectral Methods

Aziz, Zainal Abdul
coredata.dc:description: AbstractSome nonlinear wave equations are more difficult to investigate mathematically, as no general analytical method for their solutions exists. The Exponential Time Differencing (ETD) technique requires minimum stages to obtain the requiredaccurateness, which suggests an efficient technique relatingto computational duration thatensures remarkable stability characteristicsupon resolving nonlinear wave equations. This article solves the diagonal example of Kawahara equation via the ETD Runge-Kutta 4 technique. Implementation of this technique is proposed by short Matlab programs.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Exponential techniques
Integration factor techniques
ETD technique
R-K technique
Kawahara equation.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: IERI Procedia 10 ( 2014 ) 259 â€“ 265 Available online at www.sciencedirect.com 2212-6678 2014 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0/). Selection and peer review under responsibility of Information Engineering Research Institute doi: 10.1016/j.ieri.2014.09.086 ScienceDirect 2014 International Conference on Future Information Engineering Numerical Solution for Kawahara Equation by Using Spectral Methods Mohammadreza Askaripour Lahiji, Zainal Abdul Aziz * UTM Centre for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, 81310,UTM Johor Bahru, Johor, Malaysia. Abstract Some nonlinear wave equations are more difficult to investigate mathematically, as no general analytical method for their solutions exists.The Exponential Time Differencing (ETD) technique requires minimum stages to obtain the requiredaccurateness, which suggests an efficient technique relatingto computational duration thatensures remarkable stability characteristicsupon resolving nonlinear wave equations. This article solves the diagonal example of Kawahara equation via the ETD Runge-Kutta 4 technique. Implementation of this technique is proposed by short Matlab programs. Â© 2014.Published by Elsevier B.V. Selection and peer review under responsibility of Information Engineering Research Institute Keywords: Exponential techniques; Integration factor techniques; ETD technique; R-K technique, Kawahara equation. 1. Introduction A number of time-dependent partial differential equations (PDEs) are found to merge nonlinear and linear expressions of low and higher orders respectively. The spatial and temporal high order approximations can be applied suitably to find accurate numerical solutions of such problem.A lucid development of the Exact * * Corresponding author.Tel:0060197514359 E-mail address:zainalabdaziz@gmail.com 2014 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0/). Selection and peer review under responsibility of Information Engineering Research Institute 260 Mohammadreza Askaripour Lahiji and Zainal Abdul Aziz / IERI Procedia 10 ( 2014 ) 259 â€“ 265 Linear Part (ELP)techniques of any order was given by Cox and Matthews [1]. This refers much to the Exponential Time Differencing (ETD) methods [2-3]. Since then Tokman [4] expressed these formulas which direct to thegroup relating to exponential propagation methods called Exponential Propagation Iterative (EPI) techniques. In order to make better the ETD schemes, Wright [5] deliberated on these schemes and thus reforming the solution in integral form of a nonlinear autonomous system of ODEs to an extension in terms of matrix and vectorfunctions products. The basic procedure of ETD schemes is to integrate linear terms of the differential equation (DE)exactly, whilesestimating the nonlinear parts via a polynomial to be accurately integrated. Exceptionally a comparable technique is implemented by Lawson [6] and is now applied to the Integrating Factor (IF) techniques. Following in manner of IF techniques [7-9] the two ODEparts are multiplied via a suitable IF, upon which we acquired a DE with, modified variables as such the linear term isexactly resolved. The ETD schemes are used widespread to unravel stiff systems.Furthermore in [10-11], they contrasted numerous fourth-order techniques which include ETD techniques and relatedconsequences.They found preeminent option with regards to ETD Runge-Kutta 4 (ETDRK4) technique inresolving a range of one- dimensional diffusion-type problems. A wide-ranging utilization of the ETD methods was carried out in accordance with connected work in simulations of stiff problems [12]. In Aziz et al. [13-14]the ETDRK4 method was used to solve the diagonal case of Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) equation with Fourier transformation and to implement by the integration factor method.Other papers on this subject include [15- 22]. The present article is arranged as ensued: In part 1, we introduce theissue. In part 2, we demonstrate the background of the study which is related to a diagonal example. In part 3, we accomplish animplementation correlated todiagonal case of Kawahara equation, alongside Fast Fourier Transform (FFT). For part 4, a brief conclusion is given. 2. Background of the study 2.1. A diagonal example:Burgers' equation In this section, we intend to show a diagonal example, which is solved via spectral method [17]. The Burgers' equation is given as Ý‘ à¯§ àµ† Ý†Ý‘ à¯«à¯« àµ…Ý‘Ý‘ à¯« àµŒÍ² ×�Ý”áˆ¾Í²Ç¡Í³áˆ¿ , ×�Ý�áˆ¾Í²Ç¡Í³áˆ¿ (1) with the initial and Dirichlet boundary conditions imposed by means of Ý‘áˆºÝ”Ç¡Í²áˆ» àµŒáˆºÂ•Â‹Â�áˆºÍ´Ý”ß¨áˆ»áˆ» à¬¶ áˆºÍ³ àµ† Ý”áˆ» à°¯ à°® (2) where àµŒ Í·Í²Í² , Ý†àµŒÍ²Ç¤Í²Í²Í²Íµ (in lieu of viscous Burgersâ€™ equation) and Ý† àµŒÍ² (in place ofinviscid Burgersâ€™ equation), ÝŽàµŒÍ²Ç¤Í²Íµ. (5) Choosing the following substitution Ü· à·¡ àµŒÝ� à¯�à¯ž à°® à¯§ Ý‘à·œ (6) with Ü· à·¡ à¯§ àµŒÝ†Ý‡ à¬¶ Ý� à¯�à¯ž à°® à¯§ Ý‘à·œàµ…Ý� à¯�à¯ž à°® à¯§ Ý‘à·œ à¯§ , (7) andreplacing (7) in (5), we have 261 Mohammadreza Askaripour Lahiji and Zainal Abdul Aziz / IERI Procedia 10 ( 2014 ) 259 â€“ 265 Ü· à·¡ à¯§ àµ… à¬µ à¬¶ Ý…Ý‡ Ý� à¯�à¯ž à°® à¯§ Ý‘ à¬¶à·¢ àµŒÍ² . (8) Performingin Fourier space (using FFT), the numerical discretizing algorithm is achieved via Ü· à·¡ à¯§ àµ… à¯œ à¬¶ Ý� à¯�à¯ž à°® à¯§ Ý‡Ü¨àµ«áˆºÜ¨ à¬¿à¬µ àµ«Ý� à¬¿à¯�à¯ž à°® à¯§ Ü· à·¡ àµ¯áˆ» à¬¶ àµ¯àµŒÍ² . (9) whereÜ¨ is the Fourier transformed operator . The Matlab program is proposed in [17]. Fig.1. Time development ofinviscid Burgersequation (Ý†àµŒÍ²Ç¢ Left) and viscous Burgersâ€™ equation (Ý†àµ�Í² ; Right). Axes are from x = -3 to x = 3, and from t = 0 to t = 150. 3. A diagonal example: Kawahara equation Let us consider a diagonal example on the Kawahara equation, Ý‘ à¯§ àµŒàµ†Ý‘Ý‘ à¯« àµ†Ý‘ à¯«à¯«à¯« àµ…Ý‘ à¯«à¯«à¯«à¯«à¯« ×�Ý”áˆ¾Í²Ç¡Íµ Í´ß¨áˆ¿ (10) with a nonlinear hyperbolic term Ý‘Ý‘ à¯« and two linear dispersive term Ý‘ à¯«à¯«à¯« and Ý‘ à¯«à¯«à¯«à¯«à¯« . (11) The equation (10) can be written as Ý‘ à¯§ àµŒàµ†áˆº à¬µ à¬¶ Ý‘ à¬¶ áˆ» à¯« àµ†Ý‘ à¯«à¯«à¯« àµ…Ý‘ à¯«à¯«à¯«à¯«à¯« . (12) The equation is then being discretized and the Fourier spectral technique is applied to the spatial part. The Fourier transform is given by Ý‘ à¯§ à·�àµŒàµ† à¯œà¯ž à¬¶ Ý‘ à¬¶à·¢ àµ… Ý…áˆºÝ‡ à¬· àµ…Ý‡ à¬¹ áˆ» Ý‘ à·� , (13) whereÝ…àµŒÎ¾àµ†Í³ and k is the wave number. In the standard form,we have Ý‘ à¯§ àµŒ Ý‘Ü® àµ… áˆºÜ°Ý‘Ç¡Ý�áˆ», (14) where áˆºÝ‘Ü®à·œáˆ»áˆºÝ‡áˆ» àµŒ Ý…áˆºÝ‡ à¬· àµ…Ý‡ à¬¹ áˆ»Ý‘à·œáˆºÝ‡ áˆ», (15) Ü°áˆºÝ‘à·œÇ¡Ý�áˆ» àµŒ áˆºÜ°Ý‘à·œáˆ» àµŒàµ† à¯œà¯ž à¬¶ áˆºÜ¨áˆºàµ«Ü¨ à¬¿à¬µ áˆºÝ‘à·œáˆ»àµ¯ à¬¶ áˆ»áˆ», (16) and Ü¨is the discrete Fourier transform. 262 Mohammadreza Askaripour Lahiji and Zainal Abdul Aziz / IERI Procedia 10 ( 2014 ) 259 â€“ 265 Working in Fourier space, we consider the ETDRK4 time stepping for solving to Ý�àµŒÍ³Í·Í² ,with the ETDRK4 which is given as follows Ü½ à¯¡ àµŒÝ‘ à¯¡ Ý� à¯›à¯… à¬¶Î¤ àµ…àµ«Ý� à¯›à¯… à¬¶Î¤ àµ† àµ¯Ü° áˆºÝ‘ à¯¡ Ç¡Ý� à¯¡ áˆ»Ü®Î¤ , (17) Ü¾ à¯¡ àµŒÝ‘ à¯¡ Ý� à¯›à¯… à¬¶Î¤ àµ…àµ«Ý� à¯›à¯… à¬¶Î¤ àµ† àµ¯Ü° áˆºÜ½ à¯¡ Ç¡Ý� à¯¡ àµ…Ý„Î¤Í´áˆ»Ü®Î¤ (18) Ü¿ à¯¡ àµŒÜ½ à¯¡ Ý� à¯›à¯… à¬¶Î¤ àµ…àµ«Ý� à¯›à¯… à¬¶Î¤ àµ† àµ¯áˆºÍ´ áˆºÜ°Ü¾ à¯¡ Ç¡Ý� à¯¡ àµ…Ý„Î¤Í´áˆ»àµ† áˆºÜ°Ý‘ à¯¡ Ç¡Ý� à¯¡ áˆ»áˆ» Ü®Î¤ (19) Ý‘ à¯¡à¬¾à¬µ àµŒÜ½ à¯¡ Ý� à¯›à¯… àµ… (20) áˆ¼×Ž à¬µ Ü°áˆºÝ‘ à¯¡ Ç¡Ý� à¯¡ áˆ»àµ… ×ŽÍ´ à¬¶ áˆºÜ°áˆºÜ½ à¯¡ Ç¡Ý� à¯¡ àµ…Ý„Î¤Í´áˆ»àµ… áˆºÜ°Ü¾ à¯¡ Ç¡Ý� à¯¡ àµ…Ý„Î¤Í´áˆ»áˆ» àµ…×Ž à¬· Ü°áˆºÜ¿ à¯¡ Ç¡Ý� à¯¡ àµ… áˆ»Ý„áˆ½ áˆºÜ® à¬· Ý„ à¬¶ áˆ»àµ— , where ×Ž à¬µ àµŒ áˆºÜ® à¬¶ Ý„ à¬¶ àµ† ÍµÝ„Ü® àµ…Í¶áˆ»Ý� à¯›à¯… àµ†Ý„Ü® àµ†Í¶ , (21) ×Ž à¬¶ àµŒ áˆºÝ„Ü® àµ† Í´áˆ»Ý� à¯›à¯… àµ…Ý„Ü® àµ… Í´, (22) ×Ž à¬· àµŒ áˆºàµ†Ý„Ü® àµ… Í¶áˆ»Ý� à¯›à¯… àµ†Ü® à¬¶ Ý„ à¬¶ àµ† ÍµÝ„Ü® àµ†Í¶ (23) Fig.2. Time development for Kawaharaequation. Axes are from x=0 to Ý”àµŒÍµÍ´ß¨ andt=0 to t=150. 4. Conclusion We have presented the solution of Kawahara equation with the initial conditionáˆºÝ”Ç¡Í²áˆ» àµŒ à¬µà¬´à¬¹ à¬µà¬´à¬½ Ý„Ü¿Ý�Ý� à¬¸ áˆº à¯« à¬¶Î¾à¬µà¬· áˆ» , ×�Ý”áˆ¾Í²Ç¡Íµ Í´ß¨áˆ¿ , and applying N = 128 grid points in Fourier spatial discretization. For integrating the system (13), we have used the ETDRK4 method. Figure 2 shows that waves propagating and travelling periodically in time and persisting without change of shape. In spite of the remarkable sensitivity of the equation to perturbations in initial data, we obtained computational time of less than 1 second. The results are created by Matlab code (Appendix A). head.ce:title: Numerical Solution for Kawahara Equation by Using Spectral Methods

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: UTM Centre for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, 81310,UTM Johor Bahru, Johor, Malaysia

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Some nonlinear wave equations are more difficult to investigate mathematically, as no general analytical method for their solutions exists. The Exponential Time Differencing (ETD) technique requires minimum stages to obtain the requiredaccurateness, which suggests an efficient technique relatingto computational duration thatensures remarkable stability characteristicsupon resolving nonlinear wave equations. This article solves the diagonal example of Kawahara equation via the ETD Runge-Kutta 4 technique. Implementation of this technique is proposed by short Matlab programs.
